dialogues.speaker: KATHERINE MOSELEY
dialogues.text: skating alone, picks up speed, rounding the far end of th ice. KATE is 19. She is petite, but with the strength of thoroughbred. She is gorgeous, but it is a defiant beauty KATE heaves ints the grasp cf her partner, BRIAN NEUMAN, lanky, gay man of 21. THEY join hands, accelerate, and be to weave past SEVERAL OTHER PAIRS. —

dialogues.speaker: ON THE SIDELINES
dialogues.text: RICK TUTTLE, Kate’s coach, a tanned, square-jawed man cf forty, stares coldly as his skaters pass.

dialogues.speaker: KATE AND BRIAN
dialogues.text: expressions tightening, as they accelerate. Something is bothering KATE. She josties her hands, trying quickly to adjust BRIAN’s grip as they head for center ice.

dialogues.speaker: KATE
dialogues.text: (whispering urgently) Left hand under! -- Left! They grapple — their grip still uncertain as BRIAN starts te lift her from the ice, and then --

dialogues.speaker: KATE
dialogues.text: -- Stop! BRIAN hesitates -~ KATE slips from his hands ~- off balan falling -- just recovering -- landing awkwardly -- stumbl across the ice and nearly into the boards.

dialogues.speaker: TUTTLE
dialogues.text: (from the sidelines) Thirty million people just called the rest of their families in from the kitchen to watch the replay.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: KATE wheels around, furious. TUTTLE stares, disgusted.

dialogues.speaker: TUTTLE
dialogues.text: What do you think this is, Kate, Junior Pairs, 1981?

dialogues.speaker: KATE
dialogues.text: Me? You’re standing there, you just saw what happened, and you’re blaming me? OTHER COACHES and SKATERS turn. BRIAN, in the BG, stares over. TUTTLE, in no mood for backtalk, wags a reproving finger, beckoning her toward hin. CUT To:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: DOUG hurtling down the stairs, taking them three at a tim flying blindly past other ATHLETES arriving and departing from their events. DOUG charging through when --

dialogues.speaker: WOMAN'S VOICE
dialogues.text: -- Xou! DOUG stops, turns -- A young, dark, attractive, ITALIAN GIRL, dressed in a hig fashion snowsuit, stands on the landing. She steps forwar glaring. This is an angry woman.

dialogues.speaker: ITALIAN GIRL
dialogues.text: (thick Italian accent) Where you are? -~ Where you are last night? Where you are while I am waiting? DOUG hesitates, afraid to turn his back on this woman.

dialogues.speaker: ITALIAN GIRL

dialogues.speaker: DOUG
dialogues.text: (easing away) Tina, please, I --

dialogues.text: -- Tina? (she’s ready to kill) . My name is Gina! cuT TO:

dialogues.text: KATE and TUTTLE face to face in a quiet, tense conversati

dialogues.text: Rick, I’m telling you, he can’t do it.

dialogues.speaker: KATE

dialogues.speaker: TUTTLE
dialogues.text: The move stays in.

dialogues.speaker: KATE

dialogues.speaker: TUTTLE
dialogues.text: You're the one who’s not committing!

dialogues.speaker: ' KATE
dialogues.text: I‘m the one who takes the fall!

dialogues.speaker: TUTTLE
dialogues.text: You can’t fall if you don’t get your butt in the air!

dialogues.speaker: CUT TO

AN ONCOMING PASSENGER VAN -- SCREECHES TO A STOP -- inche from flattening DOUG -- he stands there, stunned as -- DOUG’S POV =~ THE VAN THE SWEDISH WOMEN’S BOBSLED TEAM -- FOUR SMILING BLONDES fight for an open window --

dialogues.speaker: SWEDISH GIRLS
dialogues.text: (as one)

dialogues.text: KATE throws her skates into a bag. JACK MOSELEY, her fath a prosperous man of 50 in a business suit, stands there.

dialogues.speaker: KATE
dialogues.text: I’m just asking you to talk to hin, Dad! Just get him to listen.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown

dialogues.speaker: JACK

dialogues.speaker: KATE
dialogues.text: (as she goes) I’ll be in my cell. cUT To

dialogues.text: THE SWEDISH VAN skids to a stop. THE GIRLS waving as DOUG dives out, racing for the building, pulling credentials a he goes. A CALGARY POLICE OFFICER stands guard. DOUG . (breathlessly) ' Doug Dorsey... U.S. Hockey team... coP (checking his tags) Hell, son, they’re just about to start -- DOUG blows past the COP -- through the door and --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: An empty passageway. DOUG is lost. Sweating. Cursing. Charging blindly ahead. From above, the MUFFLED ROAR OF T CROWD. If he could claw his way up to the ice he’d do it.

dialogues.speaker: A. DIFFERENT PASSAGEWAY
dialogues.text: KATE striding ahead -- rounding a corner and -- SHACK! -- right into DOUG -- a head-on collision and it’s no contes -- KATE sent flying on her ass --.

dialogues.speaker: DOUG
dialogues.text: (barely stopping) -- Does this go up to the ice? KATE stares at him, incredulous. "THE STAR SPANGLED BANNE begins to play in the distance.

dialogues.speaker: DOUG
dialogues.text: Is_this the way to the ice?

dialogues.speaker: KATE
dialogues.text: (still sitting there) Why you barbarian jerk -- is that all you have to say? Screw this, DOUG is already several steps away and moving

dialogues.speaker: KATE
dialogues.text: Where were you raised, in a barnyard? DOUG stops mid-stride. This kind of shit demands at least a moment of his time.

dialogues.speaker: DOUG
dialogues.text: Honey, where I’m from we stand for the National Anthen. Now he’s gone. cUuT TO:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: TWO ANNOUNCERS, BUD and GORDON, talk to the camera:

dialogues.speaker: BUD
dialogues.text: If you’re just joining us from the Men’s downhill, you’re in for a big surprise. The Hungarian Hockey team was supposed to be an easy first round mark for the U.S.

dialogues.speaker: GORDON
dialogues.text: We’re in the third period and Hungary is up by a goal...

dialogues.speaker: THE PENALTY BOX
dialogues.text: DOUG, flushed and focused, is impatiently counting down t final seconds of his incarceration. Five...four...three..

dialogues.speaker: GORDON, (OVER)
dialogues.text: Here comes Dorsey out of the penalty box. The power play is over. DOUG explodes ONTO THE ICE -- as A WHISTLE BLOWS.

dialogues.speaker: BUD, (OVER)
dialogues.text: -- And that’1ll be icing. A pause in the action. The REFEREE grabs the puck.

dialogues.speaker: BUD, (OVER)
dialogues.text: Doug Dorsey, of course, the phenom from Mahorn, Minnesota.

dialogues.speaker: GORDON, (QVER)
dialogues.text: Just a super story, Bud. Here’s a Junior from the University of Minnesota we’1ll definitely be seeing in the NHL before the year is out. Substitutions are being made. The U.S. COACH motions for DOUG who waves him off. He’s staying on the ice.

dialogues.speaker: BUD, (OVER)
dialogues.text: Incredible young athlete. Handles the puck well. Sees everything --

dialogues.speaker: GORDON
dialogues.text: And what a skater -- as graceful as anyone you’ll ever see on the ice. THE HUNGARIAN COACH paces behind the PLAYERS BENCH. He st leans down and whispers something to a huge, hulking GOON The GOON smiles toothlessly and jumps out onto the ice.

dialogues.speaker: BUD, (OVER)
dialogues.text: This is a very intense, competitive young man.

dialogues.speaker: GORDON, (OVER)
dialogues.text: He learns to control that temper and he could be one of the true greats of the game. ON THE ICE -- DOUG clustered with the OTHER PLAYERS for a face-off. The GOON nudges in beside him. DOUG jostles back -- THEY’RE starting to get rough as -- THE REFEREE drops the puck -=- and they’re off -- The puck trailing to the far side of the ice -- action th as DOUG circles, waiting for a breakaway -- The puck skitters behind the U.S. net -- a pass to -- DOU who takes it on the move and -- TWO HUNGARIAN FORWARDS charging as DOUG drops his shoulde -- fakes a pass -- does an amazing fuli-turn spin that sends the TWO HUNGARIAN FORWARDS crashing into each other

dialogues.speaker: BUD, (QVER)
dialogues.text: There goes Dorsey! -- What a move! DOUG, all alone, flying across center ice as an HUNGARIAN DEFENSEMAN rushes to cut the angle -- DOUG stops cold -- the DEFENSEMAN falls past him, into the boards -- DOUG takes off -- blitzing for the goal --

dialogues.speaker: NL
dialogues.text: The HUNGARIAN GOALIE braces as -- One of the HUNGARIAN FORWARDS lunges -~- his stick flying and into DOUG’s skates and -- DOUG begins to fall -- off balance -- going down -- still managing somehow to shoot and -- THE PUCK lifts -=- just above the GOALIE’S GLOVE and -- DoUG into the boards -- hard -- THE CROWD CHEERING and -- Out of nowhere -- THE GOON lumbering at full speed ~-- th is a man with a mission and -- DOUG, starts to his feet when -- WHAM! -- THE GOON, stick high -- ploughs into him -- a wicked, crushing blow and - FINALLY TO -~ DOUG’S HELMET skittering across the ice, past other PLAYERS and REFEREE in whose horrified expressions, we measure the seriousnes of the blow. cuT TO:

ON THE ICE -~- KATE AND BRIAN in the midst of their progr Coming out of a death spiral and striding together the le of the ice -- arm movement, filler stuff, catching their breath as they race toward their finale --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We’re really tight here -- Just the two of them, smiles Plastered on their faces, sweat bleeding through make-up the elegance of the sport revealed as the hard work it re is. MUSIC PEAKING -- faster and --

dialogues.speaker: KATE
dialogues.text: (under her breath) . Pick it up! -- Pick it up! BRIAN’s expression tightening -- KATE’s hands searching f a better grip but there’s not time -- THEY’RE INTO THE LI -- BRIAN clenches -- KATE is up -- BRIAN falters -- too l -- she’s launched -- into the air -- spinning -- around a around but -- trouble -- she’s underrotated -- off balanc

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: coming down -- her toe snags -- and BRIAN watches in horr -- KATE is falling as THE MUSIC CRASHES ITS FINAL CRESCEN and she goes sprawling across the ice --

dialogues.speaker: NETWORK FEED
dialogues.text: BRIAN alone at center ice. KATE, on her ass, yards away. The CROWD silent, as she rises slowly. TWO ANNOUNCERS -- DICK and PEGGY -- solemnly break in over the picture:

dialogues.speaker: . DICK, (QVER)
dialogues.text: Oh dear...

dialogues.speaker: PEGGY, (OVER)
dialogues.text: ...Such a difficult move...

dialogues.speaker: DICK
dialogues.text: +.-Just a heartbreaking moment, and to have it happen here... KATE stands to SYMPATHETIC APPLAUSE. She looks ashen.

dialogues.speaker: PEGGY, (OVER)
dialogues.text: It takes so much extraordinary work, and time and effort to get this far and to have it end like this... BRIAN rushes to KATE’s side, reaches for her hand. She ya it away and starts skating off the ice, leaving him behin DICK (OVER) . Kate Moseley -- My God, this just isn’t done -- She’s...she’s leaving the ice...

dialogues.speaker: LIVE ACTION -
dialogues.text: CHOKED WITH PEOPLE -- the crowd parting -- ALL EYES ON -- KATE fleeing the ice -- striding as fast as she can on skate guards, through the crowd and -- TUTTLE in the BG, disgusted watching her go, as BRIAN ska in alone from the ice and -- JACK, off to one side, shaking his head, making no move t comfort his daughter as she passes and -- KATE still coming -- FACES EVERYWHERE -- and WE’RE TRACKI WITH HER -- HAND-HELD TENSION as she stares straight ahea a stoic mask of an expression frozen on her face barely disguising the pain and fear and humiliation in her eyes the crowd, the moment, the cameras, nothing but a blur as she ploughs ahead and --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 10 INTO THE CORRIDOR == KATE still coming -- OTHER SKATERS turning as she passes -- and WE’RE IN REAL TIGHT HERE as she starts to run and her expression begins to fall apart -- tears welling as she flees and -- DISSOLVE To: EXT. CHICAGO’S MT. SINAI EYE AND EAR -~- DAY EST. SHOT -- Doctors, patients, nurses hustling in and ou

dialogues.text: A private room. Dead flowers and stacks of magazines evidence a long stay. DOUG, in jeans and T-shirt, stands at the mirror examining a shaved SCAR above his right ear He takes a deep breath, steels himself, and exits the roo

dialogues.speaker: CUT TO
dialogues.text: INT. DOCTOR‘S OFFICE -- DAY. DOUG sits nervously as his DOCTOR flips through a chart o his desk. The DOCTOR looks up, finds a smile.

dialogues.speaker: DOCTOR
dialogues.text: I hear you’ve made quite an impression on our nursing staff: A moment. DOUG says nothing, far too tense for small talk The DOCTOR shifts, summons his best professional resolve.

dialogues.speaker: DOCTOR
dialogues.text: I wish I had better news. It could be worse. Luckily, we got in fast enough to limit some of the damage. The DOCTOR glances at the chart.

dialogues.speaker: DOCTOR
dialogues.text: For the record, you've lost close to eighteen degrees of peripheral vision in your right eye. (he hesitates) In most cases, something like this would be an inconvenience, but for a hockey player, well -- DOUG’ So how long before it comes back?

dialogues.speaker: DOCTOR
dialogues.text: Different states have different driving regulations. Here in Illinois, your car would have to be equiped with a full-view mirror --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ~~ How long before it comes back? °

dialogues.speaker: DOCTOR
dialogues.text: Doug, I’m sorry, but you’ve got a blindside. It’s a permanent condition.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: pouc So there’s an operation, right?

dialogues.speaker: DOCTOR
dialogues.text: I’m afraid not.

dialogues.speaker: DOUG
dialogues.text: There is an operation! It’s just you hate to mention it because it’s so outrageously overpriced.

dialogues.speaker: DOCTOR
dialogues.text: It’s not a question of money.

dialogues.speaker: DOUG
dialogues.text: It’s dangerous, right? You open the brain -- some micro~laser thing -- you mess around, who knows what could happen -- ‘@ . : DOCTOR : Doug, I’ve specialized in opthalmic surgery for for over thirty years --

dialogues.speaker: _ DOUG
dialogues.text: Okay! So you don’t do it here! But somebody does it -- someplace, there’s a clinic, you’ve got to go to Mexico City and they inject shark piss up your nose and you’ve got to sit absolutely still for eight months and there’s a two percent survival rate and you hate to even mention it because it’s the kind of quack medicine you’ve spent your life fighting, but right now, because you see just how absolutely desperate I am you’re gonna break your solemn oath and tell me, right? (pleading)

dialogues.speaker: DOCTOR
dialogues.text: I’m very sorry, Doug... DOUG sags. Blinking back tears. Just sitting there. . DISSOLVE 7c: Ne  i2

dialogues.text: Gray skies. Cold air. Frigid spray blows off Lake Superio DOUG, workclothes covered with grease, winches down a mit gate. SUPERIMPOSE: -

dialogues.speaker: TWO_ YEARS LATER
dialogues.text: DOUG stands and stares grimly out over the canal as a bar passes in the BG.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A cinderblock gin mill in the middle of nowhere. A few ca parked out front. A rusted double-wide trailer sits out b A tin sign advertises: "DORSEY’S PENALTY BOX -- TAP AND GRILL" A pitted ‘68 Chevy pulls up. DOUG gets out, heads for the door, as his ride pulls away.

dialogues.speaker: CUT TO
dialogues.text: INT. DORSEY’S TAP AND GRILL -- DAY A warm bar in a cold place. Hockey stuff everywhere: posters, sticks, pennants up all over. A COUPLE DRUNKS hunched over shots at the end of the rail. WALTER DORSEY, Doug’s older brother, a big, beefy guy in his thirties stands behind the bar, lost in a newspaper. - " pOUG’S VOICE Any mail? WALT looks up to see DOUG heading his way.

dialogues.speaker: WALT
dialogues.text: Hey... You’re early.

dialogues.speaker: DOUG
dialogues.text: (arriving at the bar) Ate in the car. Any mail?

dialogues.speaker: WALT
dialogues.text: {ignoring the question) Propane stopped by. I had him leave three tanks for the trailer.

dialogues.speaker: DOUG
dialogues.text: Something came, didn’t it? (Walt hesitates) You opened it, right? -- How many times do I have to tell you --

dialogues.speaker: WALT
dialogues.text: -- Hesh opened it. (down the bar) Tell him, Hesh! DOUG turns, angrily. HESH, a skinny, old drunk hunches do

dialogues.speaker: DOUG
dialogues.text: It’s bad enough my brother thinks he can go through my goddamned --

dialogues.speaker: WALT
dialogues.text: -- Hey, Doug. (Doug turns) We were all just hoping for good news.

dialogues.speaker: DOUG
dialogues.text: (instantly deflated) Read it.

dialogues.speaker: WALT
dialogues.text: Dougie, come on...

dialogues.speaker: . DOUG
dialogues.text: Read it, Walter. WALT reluctantly pulls the letter from his pocket, reads:

dialogues.speaker: WALT
dialogues.text: "We regret to inform you that at this time, our hockey program is not offering try-outs to unrecruited players." DOUG takes the blow. Looks around.

dialogues.speaker: WALT
dialogues.text: You want a beer? Have a beer.

dialogues.speaker: DOUG
dialogues.text: No. I/11 catch you later. (starting away) Sorry, Hesh. Silence. Long faces listening, as.DOUG SLAMS OUT THE DOOR cuT To:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A pick-up HOCKEY GAME in progress. DOUG the oldest player by far. These KIDS may be young, but they’re good. DOUG moving the puck up the ice, looking like a giant out ther -- blowing past EVERYONE -- slowing to shoot when -- PEE WEE -- the smallest kid on the ice -- slips in on his blindside -- stripping the puck off DOUG’S stick --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: DOUG turns -- too late -- BEE WEE stoking away with the puck. DOUG left standing there, looking whipped.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Domed roof. Regulation ice. State of the art. Dramatic contrast to the pond. A BRAHMS CONCERTO fills the space. ON THE ICE -- KATE and a NEW PARTNER skating -- an arabes -- into a side-by-side sit spin -- KATE looking perfect, NEW PARTNER, however, loses his edge and falls --

dialogues.speaker: KATE
dialogues.text: (stopping cold) Oh come on...! The MUSIC STOPS. PARTNER stares over like a beaten dog.

dialogues.speaker: PARTNER
dialogues.text: Sorry, Kate, I’ll get it. (to someone off ice) Can we try it again? ANTON PAMCHENKO -- Kate’s current coach, starts out onto ice. ANTON is a man who has come a long way through diffi times. A quiet reserve. Eyes always probing. An abrasive exterior belies a warm, knowing soul.

dialogues.speaker: ' ANTON
dialogues.text: (a thick Russian accent) We are in one piece? ” KATE ‘This guy is taking us nowhere.

dialogues.speaker: ANTON
dialogues.text: Katya, please...

dialogues.speaker: PARTNER
dialogues.text: I can’t concentrate like this! (pleading) Every move -- every day -- she’s turning me into a nervous wreck! KATE, unmoved, is already on her way off the ice.

dialogues.speaker: KATE
dialogues.text: I’ve got laundry that can skate better than that.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: OFF THE ICE -- ANTON and JACK MOSELEY in conversation. In the BG, KATE on the ice. Skating alone. Working hard.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You should’ve been making her singles skater.

dialogues.speaker: JACK
dialogues.text: You’re sure it’s too late? ANTON shoots him a look that says it’s much too late.

dialogues.speaker: JACK
dialogues.text: So where do we go from here?

dialogues.speaker: ANTON
dialogues.text: Two years, eight partners. This one is too small. That one too big. Too loud. Too much sweat. Not enough sweat --

dialogues.speaker: JACK
dialogues.text: So dig a little deeper.

dialogues.speaker: ANTON
dialogues.text: We hit bottom rock, Mr. Moseley. Let me tell you how is: I go to rink. I see skater. If I like -- if I see even spark of hope, I talk. Of course, skater says to me finally, "Who is partner?" (he shakes his head) . Reputation is like plague. {Jack stiffens) : Please...she is tremendous skater. Everyone is saying this. Petite. Powerful. But then always is coming the big "B"... (an American accent) “Whatta bitch."

dialogues.speaker: JACK
dialogues.text: (bristling) What about Spindler? Kate said you spoke to him, that he was on the fence.

dialogues.speaker: ANTON
dialogues.text: I spare feelings. Spindler says before he skates with her he wears garlic from neck and sleeps with cross.

dialogues.speaker: JACK
dialogues.text: (stone cold) There’s a month left on your contract. Find someone who can cut it or get off the payroll.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 16 INT. ANTON’S BEDROOM -- NIGHT Spartan. The room of a refugee. A PHOTOGRAPH of ANTON as a much younger man on skates. A SILENT TV plays in the BG

dialogues.speaker: _ ANTON, (OVER)
dialogues.text: +.-but difficulties are in past. Is mature young woman now -- ' THE CAMERA FINDS ANTON -=- on the phone, a week-long gr of beard evidences some busy days. As he listens to what apparently unpleasant news, he reachs down to pour himsel SHOT OF VODKA from a bottle on the nightstand.

dialogues.speaker: ANTON
dialogues.text: (into the phone) .«.-Of course...Yes, I understand, thank you, anyway. He hangs up. Downs the shot. He glances at the TV, before picking up the remote control and CLICKING THE VOLUME UP

dialogues.speaker: THE TV
dialogues.text: ANTON watches -- expressionless for a moment. And then hi eyes come alive. He leans in. Thinking. >

dialogues.speaker: CUT TO
dialogues.text: EXT. DOUG’S POND -- NIGHT Cheap floodlights strung from makeshift plywood posts cas an uneven glare on a small section of the ice. Steel drus are spaced every few yards -- an obstacle course. DOUG, hockey stick in hand, speeds across the ice -- in the ami of a grueling kamikaze drill -- slaloming in and out of t barrels -- backward -- forward -- an amazing display of skating ability. Pouring sweat, heaving for breath, he st He wipes his brow, then suddenly turns, hearing something ANTON at the edge of the pond applauding. He stops.

dialogues.speaker: ANTON
dialogues.text: Ice is safe? Sign has warning.

dialogues.speaker: DOUG
dialogues.text: So don’t skate. ANTON shrugs, starts walking out. ANTON . You skate very strong. Beautiful line. Much power. Weight transfer is perfection. (he smiles) I see many tapes. DOUG, winded, watches him approach suspiciously.  aes

dialogues.speaker: DOUG
dialogues.text: Look, pal, if you’re a reporter, you’re a little late. The story’s been done.

dialogues.speaker: ANTON
dialogues.text: I am wondering if you are this strong in upper body?

dialogues.speaker: DOUG
dialogues.text: What’re you, some kind of twinkie?

dialogues.speaker: ANTON,
dialogues.text: I am coach.

dialogues.speaker: DOUG
dialogues.text: You're kidding... (an instant, total transformation) Look, hey, I’m sorry -- Are you the guy from B.U.? -= You are, right? The Swedish guy, right? (before he can answer) Ww. ! (standing tall) Upper body? -- I’m a rock. I’m in the best shape of my life -- I’m benching three-hundred. Weight training, roadwork, speed drills -- (shifting gears) ~- Hey, I know I had a rep -- I mean, who’re we fooling right? The girls, the partying, the goofing off -- it was a problem, no question --

dialogues.speaker: ANTON
dialogues.text: -- I am not hockey coach.

dialogues.speaker: DOUG
dialogues.text: Huh...? ANTON opens a gym bag hanging off his shoulder, begins fishing out something that WE CAN’T SEE.

dialogues.speaker: ANTON
dialogues.text: You wear size eleven, yes?

dialogues.speaker: DOUG
dialogues.text: What the hell is this?

dialogues.speaker: ANTON
dialogues.text: Maybe nothing. You try.

dialogues.speaker: DOUG
dialogues.text: (looking down) Those are figure skates, pal.  23 On that -- a SUDDEN HUGE SNAPPING SOUND -- DOUG looks dow BETWEEN HIS LEGS -- a jagged faultline -- the ice has cra

dialogues.speaker: GREENWICH CONNECTICUT
dialogues.text: PULL BACK TO FIND -- A STRETCH LIMOUSINE turning off.”

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Easing up a country lane. -Stopping at a large iron gate, bordered by a daunting, high stone wall. THE GATE swings open and THE LIMO pulls up a winding estate driveway.

dialogues.speaker: INSIDE THE LIMO
dialogues.text: DOUG, lost in the expanse of this huge backseat lounge, stares out the window at the incredible passing scenery.

dialogues.speaker: DOUG
dialogues.text: Holy shit... Up ahead, a sprawling, two-story, TUDOR STONE COTTAGE.

dialogues.speaker: DRIVER
dialogues.text: (veddy British) That sir, is the pool house. DOUG sits back. Blown away.

dialogues.speaker: THE MOSELEY ESTATE
dialogues.text: is world class. THE LIMO PASSES -- tennis courts, olympic pool, a fifteen car garage and finally around a circular driveway, stopping in front of -- A huge STONE MANSION. DOUG exits the limo, looking around, dumbfounded. ON THE MANSION STEPS -- ANTON stares down, watching DOUG’ reaction. . curT TO:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ANTON and DOUG walking along when DOUG suddenly stops --

dialogues.speaker: DOUG
dialogues.text: You gotta be kidding... UF AHEAD -- A DOMED PRIVATE INDOOR RINK. cuT TO:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ANTON and DOUG enter. A TCHAIKOVSKY SYMPHONY blaring. ON THE ICE -- KATE, in white tights and skirt, skates alo to the MUSIC. She makes no sign of recognition, but knows full-well she’s being watched. Twirling and preening -- she’s putting on a real show. DOUG takes a good look. He smiles. He likes what he sees. ANTON moves to the sound system -- KILLS THE MUSIC.

dialogues.speaker: ANTON
dialogues.text: Come... ANTON and DOUG head down the RUNWAY and start walking tow center ice. The closer they get, the bigger DOUG’s smile. KATE turns, feigns surprise -- and then her expression so

dialogues.speaker: KATE
dialogues.text: That’s not Spindler! ‘ ANTON shrugs. Guilty as charged.

dialogues.speaker: KATE
dialogues.text: Where the hell is Spindler? You said --

dialogues.speaker: ANTON
dialogues.text: -- You said Spindler. This is Dorsey. Douglas Dorsey. : She examines DOUG as if he were an insect.

dialogues.speaker: KATE
dialogues.text: Dorsey? Never head of hin.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Douglas is beautiful skater. ‘KATE steps back, a look of mounting horror forming --

dialogues.speaker: KATE
dialogues.text: You’re...you’re that hockey player. DOUG’s smile fades.

dialogues.speaker: . ANTON
dialogues.text: Is try-out.

dialogues.speaker: DOUG
dialogues.text: Nice to-meet you. He offers his hand. She stares at it with epic distaste.  20

dialogues.speaker: ANTON
dialogues.text: I said, is try-out. Reluctantly, KATE moves to shake -- one touch and --

dialogues.speaker: KATE
dialogues.text: (recoiling instantly) -- ny God!

dialogues.speaker: DOUG
dialogues.text: - What? -- My hands?

dialogues.speaker: KATE
dialogues.text: What do you do, soak them in battery acid?

dialogues.speaker: DOUG
dialogues.text: Look, I’m sorry...I guess they’re a little rough, but hey... (he tries a smile) I’ve never had any complaints -before.

dialogues.speaker: KATE
dialogues.text: (stone cold) I’m terribly impressed. (turning on Anton} What is this, the final stages of Ukranian alcohol psychosis?

dialogues.speaker: DOUG
dialogues.text: (to Anton) Wait a minute -- who’s checking out who here?

dialogues.speaker: KATE
dialogues.text: (wheeling on Doug) I don’t know how many slapshots you’ve taken to the brain, but this was your audition, and let me assure you, it’s over. They’re off and running. ANTON can only stare back and fo

dialogues.speaker: DOUG
dialogues.text: Yo! -- Snow White, put a clamp on it. I’m here scoping you out. I told this guy from minute-one that the idea of strapping on pink skates and throwing some teeny~bopper rink-rat around the ice was not my idea of a happening experience!

dialogues.speaker: KATE
dialogues.text: (to Anton) Get him out of my building.  (e®

dialogues.speaker: DOUG
dialogues.text: (to Anton) Temperamental? Lemme tell you, I got another word for it.

dialogues.speaker: KATE
dialogues.text: (to Anton) Is that what you told him?

dialogues.speaker: DOUG
dialogues.text: What -- like it’s a secret?

dialogues.speaker: KATE
dialogues.text: Who the hell do you think you are?

dialogues.speaker: DOUG
dialogues.text: I know exactly who I am -- I‘ma guy who came a long way for lunch.

dialogues.speaker: KATE
dialogues.text: Well, don’t let me keep you from the trough.

dialogues.speaker: DOUG
dialogues.text: (to Anton) Sorry, buddy, I wouldn’t wish this on a snake. I’m outta here. DOUG starts away. KATE heading the opposite direction -- KATE and DOUG KATE about to

dialogues.speaker: ENOUGH
dialogues.text: stop in their tracks.

dialogues.speaker: ANTON ,
dialogues.text: Introduction is over! Conversation is over! (to Kate) Attitude is over! (to Doug) Insecurity is over! (to them both) Mouth closed! Ears open! speak --

dialogues.speaker: ANTON
dialogues.text: (cutting her off) Is end of line! Pairs means two! You have no partner, you are skating nowhere! All bridges are burning. Name is mud. Yes, is crazy choice. But only crazy choices are being left! KATE stares at him, shocked, chastened.

dialogues.speaker: DOUG
dialogues.text: Look, man --

dialogues.speaker: . ANTON
dialogues.text: (cutting him off) And what is for you? Back to Siberia? Skating on pond is big excitement? Hockey for you is over. Kaput. Who else but me is being so insane to take chance on you? DOUG looks small all of a sudden. Silence.

dialogues.speaker: ANTON
dialogues.text: Good. We skate.

dialogues.speaker: CUT TO
dialogues.text: BLACK SKATES across the ice to...WHITE SKATES. PULL BACK TO REVEAL -- DOUG, wearing a Chicago Blackhawks T-shirt and hockey sweats, standing behind KATE. Both of them stone-faced. ANTON, on skates, circles DOUG, inspect

dialogues.speaker: ANTON
dialogues.text: Chest high... As he directs, they respond and adjust.

dialogues.speaker: ANTON
dialogues.text: More...Arms to side, loose...they Rang, but there is life -- Now, left hand around her waist. DOUG hesitates. KATE braces. ANTON slides in -- pulls DOUG’s hand into position. This is suddenly very intimate

dialogues.speaker: ANTON
dialogues.text: Katya, shoulders relax...relax. KATE, teeth clenched, lets her shoulders fall. ANTON plac DOUG’s right hand in hers. She flinches. ANTON skates bac a few yards, admiring the two of then. '

dialogues.speaker: ANTON
dialogues.text: Goed. Line is beautiful. (as he circles) I am counting a beat. On four you will push off. Katya, you will lead. Slowly -- a large eight. Douglas you will push left with her left -- right with right. She will show the way. All will be smooth and easy... (a slow rythmn) One two one -- one two two -- one two three -- one two four <= (continuing as-~)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: THEY'RE OFF -- a jerky, false start -- but DOUG hangs in and -- stroke -- and stroke and -- AROUND THE ICE -- and KATE’s not helping him any, but she doesn’t have to becau he’s picking this up fast ~- and by the time they make th second turn he’s starting to synch -- ANTON . Good! -- Heads up! -- Long strokes!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: DOUG AND KATE as they glide. She knows what she’s doing. “He has to concentrate. Close quarters.

dialogues.speaker: . KATE
dialogues.text: What do you do, shower once a week?

dialogues.speaker: DOUG -
dialogues.text: That an invitation? KATE accelerates. DOUG almost slips.

dialogues.speaker: ANTON
dialogues.text: (calling over) Enough! Center ice, please. First position. They stop. Skate back beside ANTON, who quickly arranges them as they were in the beginning -- DOUG behind KATE.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Katya, lock arms please. KATE complies, elbows angled at her sides.

dialogues.speaker: ANTON
dialogues.text: Douglas, please to pick her up. DOUG looks at him. -He’s serious. DOUG puts his hands beneath KATE’s elbows and lifts her effortlessly.

dialogues.speaker: ANTON
dialogues.text: Enough. We are finished.

dialogues.speaker: KATE
dialogues.text: I told you this was ridiculous. (still up there) Will you please put me down! DOUG lets go -= KATE drops like a stone, flat on her ass.

dialogues.speaker: DOUG
dialogues.text: Guess that move needs some work.

dialogues.speaker: KATE
dialogues.text: You_psychopath!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 24 DOUG pushes off, skating for the runway.

dialogues.speaker: DOUG
dialogues.text: It’s been a gas working with you. Good luck with the next victim.

dialogues.speaker: ANTON
dialogues.text: We start tomorrow morning at eight.

dialogues.speaker: DOUG AND KATE
dialogues.text: (simultaneously) What? cUuT TO:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A two-story outbuilding down the lawn from the Mansion. Two apartments, one on either floor.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Pleasant. Comfortably furnished. Currently vacant. DOUG looking around. ANTON behind hin.

dialogues.speaker: ANTON
dialogues.text: Free room and board. Expenses. Allowance. We are working seven days a week without break. You eat, breathe, and sleep pairs skating. DOUG . Look, it was great getting out of town, but I yot work tomorrow. ANTON . You train with me, I promise you are making wonderful living on skates the rest of your life.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Let’s not screw around. I can’t do this and you know it.

dialogues.speaker: ANTON
dialogues.text: I don’t play games. Is too late.

dialogues.speaker: DOUG
dialogues.text: You know what I do when I see figure skating? It’s a three choice situation: either I leave the rink, change the channel, or laugh my ass off. ANTON opens a closet beside a television and VCR, inside are hundreds of SKATING VIDEOS.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Then you will have much to amuse you. CUT To:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A CORPORATE HELICOPTER HEAVES INTO FRAME, touching down on a landing pad. JACK MOSELEY, business suit, briefcase in hand, exits the chopper and jogs toward the mansion.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: JACK hands his coat to an OLD BUTLER as KATE rips into hi

dialogues.speaker: KATE
dialogues.text: -~- I'd like to know how much you had to do with this!

dialogues.speaker: JACK
dialogues.text: Honey, the bottom line is: Can he skate?

dialogues.speaker: KATE
dialogues.text: You knew he was coming and you never said a word!

dialogues.speaker: JACK
dialogues.text: (dismissing the Butler) Thank you, Martin. KATE and JACK stand there a moment as the BUTLER departs.

dialogues.speaker: JACK
dialogues.text: (all business now) If you’re telling me this guy can’t skate, if you’re saying that Anton’s gone round the bend and that you’re sure -- absolutely sure -- this is a waste of time, then that’s one thing. But if you’re quitting on me, Kate, if this is your way of telling me you've lost your stomach for it, then we better sit down and talk. KATE stands there, looking lost. Very much undecided.

dialogues.speaker: JACK
dialogues.text: Good. You had me worried there. JACK brushes a strand of hair from her shoulder.

dialogues.speaker: JACK
dialogues.text: / I’ll take a look at hin.  26

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The room is oak-panelled, but it’s hard to notice because every square inch is covered with TROPHIES, MEDALS, and PHOTOS OF KATE SKATING SINCE SHE WAS FOUR. JACK sits behi his desk. DOUG, across from him, is slouched in an armcha

dialogues.speaker: JACK
dialogues.text: Let me tell you how I run my business: I hire the very best people I can get my hands on and I leave them alone until they disappoint me or I can find somebody better. You’ve heard of the Moscow Central Army Sports Club? (Doug nods) Anton was their pride and joy. When it comes to skating I don’t think there’s anybody who knows more. So I trust him. I have to. He says you’re something special. He tells me he can work around your eye problen. . (beat) What do you think?

dialogues.speaker: . DOUG
dialogues.text: I think you must be in pretty sad shape to come after me. JACK sits back. Off balance and not used to it.

dialogues.speaker: DOUG
dialogues.text: So who else is in on this?

dialogues.speaker: JACK
dialogues.text: What do you mean by that?

dialogues.speaker: DOUG
dialogues.text: When you’re done, do I have to go talk to mom and the rest of the family?

dialogues.speaker: JACK
dialogues.text: (flatly) Kate is an only child. Her mother died when she was six. JACK lets him hang there a moment.

dialogues.speaker: DOUG
dialogues.text: Sorry. It’s been a long day.

dialogues.speaker: JACK
dialogues.text: You stay with us and you’ll have a lot of long days.  Ne A beat. JACK measures DOUG. JACK points to

dialogues.speaker: JACK
dialogues.text: I understand you and I have one thing in common.

dialogues.speaker: DOUG
dialogues.text: What’s that?

dialogues.speaker: JACK
dialogues.text: I don't like to lose either. AN EMPTY GLASS DISPLAY CASE on his desk.

dialogues.speaker: JACK
dialogues.text: You see this? -- There’s an Olympic Gold medal belongs in there. We’re winners in this house. We’ve always been winners. Kate is a winner. (his eyes linger on the empty case) And this damn thing...this is our veminder of what happens when you hitch your wagon to a dud. (he looks up) See, Doug, pairs skating, more than anything else, is about trust. You trust that I’m gonna throw you high enough in the air, and I trust that when you come down, you’re not gonna put a blade in my back. I can never skate any better than you let me. DOUG stares back, stone-faced. A cipher.

dialogues.speaker: JACK
dialogues.text: Now Brian Newman could skate. And unlike you, he wasn’t a reclamation project. But you couldn’t trust him. He wasn’t what I’d call a pressure player. When the whip came down, Brian folded and Kate ended up looking like a fool. JACK lifts a stack of papers on his desk for DOUG to see. JACK balls the

dialogues.speaker: JACK
dialogues.text: These are scouting reports. Male skaters. Thirty-five wash-outs. (pulling the one on top) Wagner...no stamina. paper in his hand -- tosses it across his desk toward a garbage can -- missing.  23

dialogues.speaker: JACK
dialogues.text: (taking the next) Myersohn...no rhythm. JACK crumples this one -=- tosses it -- missing again.

dialogues.speaker: JACK
dialogues.text: (in quick succesion) Leone...Parnes...Hudler... (he misses all three, focuses on Doug) Are you a pressure player, Doug? Or is everyone wasting their time? Without a word, DOUG, leans forward, takes the next page on the stack, crushes it quickly in his hand and flips it effortlessly toward the garbage can -- THE PAPER arcs far across the room -- BING! Dead perfect.

dialogues.speaker: JACK
dialogues.text: Lucky shot.

dialogues.speaker: DOUG
dialogues.text: I say I make it again. (he grins) Double or nothing my allowance. JACK smiles, pushes the stack toward him.

dialogues.speaker: JACK 7
dialogues.text: You’re on.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: KATE at the keyhole -- a baffling silence. Suddenly, THE DOORS FLY OPEN -- JACK and DOUG exit the study, all smile

dialogues.speaker: JACK
dialogues.text: (putting an arm over Doug’s shoulder) Great to have you aboard, son! (looking up) Kate, there you are... KATE stares in horror at this tableau of fraternity.

dialogues.speaker: DOUG
dialogues.text: Great meeting you, Jack... (he glances at Kate, smiles broadly) »--and I’11 catch your act tomorrow. cuT To:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 29 INT. THE BUTLER’S BEDROOM Dark. Proper. MARTIN, the eldery butler, reading in bed, hears something -- looks up over bifocals.

dialogues.speaker: MARTIN
dialogues.text: Well... KATE, wearing a nightgown, steps into the room, closing t door furtively behind her. Silence. She stands there.

dialogues.speaker: MARTIN
dialogues.text: It’s been a while, hasn’t it? KATE nods. Something needy in her expression.

dialogues.speaker: / MARTIN
dialogues.text: That bad? (she nods again) I’m an old man, Kate. (she shrugs) We'll be very tired in the morning.

dialogues.speaker: KATE
dialogues.text: I won’t tell if you won’t. MARTIN cuts the thinnest of smiles. KATE brightens.

dialogues.speaker: WIPE TO
dialogues.text: MARTIN’S ROOM -- TWO HOURS LATER KATE and MARTIN sprawled on a couch, chastely bundled in nightclothes and blankets -= watching TV -~- popcorn, coo potato chips, strewn everywhere. KATE is weeping. MARTIN, huddled in robe and nightcap, looks pretty choked-up hims ACROSS THE ROOM -- ON TV -- A VIDEOTAPE runs the final, tear-stained moments of "Dark Victory." DISSOLVE To:

dialogues.speaker: INT.
dialogues.text: DOUG at center ice, staring straight ahead. ANTON, carryi a dozen plastic cones, stands with KATE off to one side. As this scene plays, ANTON, testing the perimeters of DOU visual problem, moves KATE around the ice.

dialogues.speaker: ANTON
dialogues.text: We start here -- you are seeing her?

dialogues.speaker: DOUG
dialogues.text: Nope. ANTON drops a cone, pulls KATE forward to the next positi

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (calling over) If you’re so good, why didn’t you just skate solo? (silence, he turns--) ©

dialogues.speaker: ANTON
dialogues.text: Eyes forward! (Doug turns back) You are seeing here? DOUG shakes his head no. ANTON drops a cone. They move on

dialogues.speaker: DOUG
dialogues.text: It’s a reasonable question.

dialogues.speaker: ANTON
dialogues.text: Tell him.

dialogues.speaker: __ KATE
dialogues.text: (grudgingly) I wouldn’t. do the compulsories.

dialogues.speaker: DOUG
dialogues.text: You mean, those figure eights and stuff? Wouldn’t or couldn’t?

dialogues.speaker: KATE
dialogues.text: I detested the entire procedure.

dialogues.speaker: ANTON
dialogues.text: (stopping) Compulsories require patience. (Kate shoots him a look) What about here?:

dialogues.speaker: DOUG
dialogues.text: Got it. ANTON drops two cones, checking the angles. KATE breaks f

dialogues.speaker: . KATE
dialogues.text: Talk about hiring the handicapped.

dialogues.speaker: DOUG
dialogues.text: Hey, if we’re gonna work together, you might try and be polite.

dialogues.speaker: KATE
dialogues.text: You’re not going to be here long ~ enough to make it worth the effort.

dialogues.speaker: DOUG
dialogues.text: Don’t think I/11 be able to put up with your shit?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (as she passes) I don’t think you can skate.

dialogues.speaker: DOUG
dialogues.text: There’s only two things I do really well and skating’s one of them.

dialogues.speaker: KATE
dialogues.text: Grunting around the ice with a stick in your hand is not skating.

dialogues.speaker: DOUG
dialogues.text: Honey, when it comes to hockey, you haven’t, got a clue. (beat) Aren’t you going to ask me what the second thing is?

dialogues.speaker: KATE
dialogues.text: God, you really are a neanderthal.

dialogues.speaker: DOUG
dialogues.text: Sorry to disappoint you, but I’m from Minnesota. KATE stares over, incredulous. DOUG smiles -- he's joking

dialogues.speaker: DOUG
dialogues.text: What do you do for fun? Polish your knife collection?

dialogues.speaker: KATE
dialogues.text: I’m sure there’s nothing I do that you’d find exciting. I don’t open beer bottles with my toes. I don’t sit around and count what’s left of my teeth. I don’t even enjoy watching a good tractor-pull. It’s a very limited existence, but I’ve gotten used to it.

dialogues.speaker: DOUG
dialogues.text: Life of the party, huh? (he starts to stretch) Place must be crawling with guys.

dialogues.speaker: KATE
dialogues.text: (biting at this) For your information, I do have a boyfriend.

dialogues.speaker: DOUG
dialogues.text: There’s a rough gig. What do you do, keep him chained in the basement?

dialogues.speaker: KATE
dialogues.text: Hale, at the moment, is working in my father’s London office. He’s an MBA. Harvard? Maybe you’ve heard of it, they have a hockey team.

dialogues.speaker: DOUG
dialogues.text: Must be a very sharp guy. (she looks at hin, suspicious) I’1l bet. you look all right from a couple thousand miles away. cuUT TO:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Center ice. ANTON facing DOUG and KATE.

dialogues.speaker: ANTON
dialogues.text: In hockey, everything is low. Center of gravity is low. Weight transfer is low. Shoulders are low.

dialogues.speaker: KATE ,
dialogues.text: You forgot intelligence.

dialogues.speaker: ANTON
dialogues.text: (shooting her a look) Here, for us, everything is line. , Everything is grace. For pairs skating, is one thing means entire game: Man and woman together make flower. You, Douglas, are sten. Man is support, strength, fiber. Katya is petal. She is beauty, radiance, delicacy. Is flower, you understand? (language drifting) Tsvyeetoch’niy.

dialogues.speaker: DOUG
dialogues.text: So what’s Russian for poison ivy? . cUuT TO: INT. DOUG’S BEDROOM -- BEFORE DAWN ANTON enters the dark room, hits the lights. DOUG, dead _ asleep pulls the blankets over his head and -- CUE MUSIC -- our TRAINING THEME -- we’re into a MONTAGE.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: KATE, lacing up, watching ANTON work DOUG on the ice.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: DOUG and ANTON running through the woods. The CAMERA PULL AHEAD -- KATE, way out front, looking fresh.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: State-of-the-art. DOUG toiling at a Nautilus machine, glancing between reps at -- KATE, across the room, every hair in place, as she muscles a rowing machine.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A padded floor. KATE in mid-air, hanging by a LEATHER HARNESS as ANTON demonstrates a lift for DOUG.

dialogues.speaker: WIPE TO
dialogues.text: INT. ANTON’S APARTMENT -- NIGHT The mirror image of DOUG’S upstairs studio. ANTON eats. DOUG, head down on the table, is dead asleep.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Center ice. KATE stahding stoically. DOUG staring at ANTO

dialogues.speaker: DOUG
dialogues.text: You want my hands where? ANTON points. KATE braces. DOUG exhales, shakes his head, and slips his hand gingerly between KATE’s legs.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A QUICK SERIES OF FALLS -- changes of clothing evidence t these are happening over a period of weeks. KATE falls... DOUG slips... KATE trips up DOUG... DOUG trips over KATE... KATE and DOUG collide...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: DOUG pulls off a WORN-OUT, BEATEN SKATE and hands it to ANTON for his inspection. ANTON shakes his head.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A STREAM OF SPARKS pouring from a GRINDING WHEEL as a SKA BLADE, being sharpened, strains against the stone.  34

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: KATE and ANTON stand back as an OLD CRAFTSMAN works the w This place is clearly a landmark -- a century’s worth of and grime coats the entire cluttered space. DOUG, off to one side, stares at the WALL -- covered with hundreds of yellowing, autographed PHOTOGRAPHS of skaters who’ve journeyed here over the years. boUuG . (reading the names) Lutz...Axel...Sal-chow... He looks up to see ANTON watching hin.

dialogues.speaker: DOUG
dialogues.text: You mean these moves are named after actual people? Before ANTON can answer, the CRAFTSMAN, turns sharply --

dialogues.speaker: CRAFTSMAN
dialogues.text: It’s Sal-kow. Ulrich Salchow. (eyes boring on Doug) The world didn’t start last week, young man. DOUG swallows. The CRAFTSMAN shakes his head ‘with disgus turns back to the wheel. ANTON gestures for KATE and DOUG to leave -- .

dialogues.speaker: ANTON
dialogues.text: Why don’t I meet you across the street?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: KATE and DOUG seated in this elegant little bistro, silen examining menus. A WAITER sides to the table.

dialogues.speaker: WAITER
dialogues.text: You’re waiting for a third party?

dialogues.speaker: KATE
dialogues.text: Yes, but we’1ll go ahead.

dialogues.speaker: DOUG WAITER
dialogues.text: I’ll have -- Madam -- KATE stares at DOUG, then turns to the WAITER.

dialogues.speaker: KATE
dialogues.text: I’d like the aparagus and the Calamari Salad. Four wedges of lemon. No dressing. No oil. The WAITER scribbles, turns to DOUG --

dialogues.speaker: DOUG
dialogues.text: Is there a burger on here? (Kate groans) . You have a problem? KATE . No. You have the problen. The WAITER stands-by uncomfortably.

dialogues.speaker: DOUG
dialogues.text: (to the Waiter) Blind date. (staring at Kate as he orders) I'd like a cheeseburger, a well- done, friendly, all-American, missionary-position, cheeseburger please.

dialogues.speaker: WAITER
dialogues.text: I’m afraid, sir, that we don’t have any ground beef in the house this afternoon.

dialogues.speaker: KATE
dialogues.text: (to the’ Waiter) Food frightens him. He talks tough but he’s actually a very timid young man. DOUG glares. THE WAITER looks back and forth nervously.

dialogues.speaker: DOUG
dialogues.text: Just bring me what she’s having.

dialogues.speaker: WAITER
dialogues.text: The Calamari, sir?

dialogues.speaker: DOUG
dialogues.text: Sure. - Just make mine well done.

dialogues.speaker: WAITER
dialogues.text: Well done isn’t really -

dialogues.speaker: KATE
dialogues.text: I’d love to see your expression, but it’s not worth wasting the meal. You just ordered squid salad.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (challenged now) You think I won’t eat squid?

dialogues.speaker: KATE
dialogues.text: I don’t think you can spell squid.

dialogues.speaker: DOUG
dialogues.text: (to the Waiter) Bring it on.

dialogues.speaker: WAITER
dialogues.text: Yes sir. Anything to drink? » DOUG I’ll have a draft beer. Whatever goes best with squid. And bring my date here a glass of diet cyanide.

dialogues.text: MONTAGE THEME AGAIN == ANTON at a VIDEO CAMERA, filming - DOUG and KATE as they skate. This. is getting more comple DOUG. lifting her on the move -- his hands all over her b turning -- landing her awkwardly and -- WIPE To: INT. . ANTON’S APARTMENT -- DAY DOUG at the table, staring as MARTIN sets a huge Thanksgi feast before him. ANTON enters from the kitchen, places a iced bottle of vodka and three shot glasses on the table.

dialogues.speaker: DOUG
dialogues.text: What have we here?

dialogues.speaker: ANTON
dialogues.text: We break training today. (to the Butler as he pours the shots) You are joining us, Martin? MARTIN looks up, interested. DOUG a little surprised.

dialogues.speaker: ANTON
dialogues.text: (expansive) Of course you are. Thanksgiving is most special holiday for me.

dialogues.speaker: DOUG
dialogues.text: Thanksgiving? In Russia?

dialogues.speaker: ANTON
dialogues.text: No, I defect on Thanksgiving. Paris, November 27, 1974.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 37 ANTON hands them shots. Raises his glass.

dialogues.speaker: ANTON
dialogues.text: Let us drink to Pilgrims. The three men touch glasses and drink.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: DOUG and ANTON staring out over Long Island Sound, passin a bottle of champagne, as the sun drops over the horizon.

dialogues.speaker: ANTON
dialogues.text: ».+-Z was very imaginative thinker. Big ideas. Dreams like cowboy western. America, I am sure, will be falling at my feet like drunk on sidewalk. (laughing at the memory) Here I am! -- I am coaching nine European Champions. I am coaching seven World Champions. Four gold Olympics. I am Burt Lancaster! (a wistful pause) So I come. I wait. Where is Cadillac? Where is red carpet? Big ideas need much feeding. Soon is no more Burt Lancaster in mirror. DOUG reaches in his pocket, pulls a LARGE TURKEY DRUMSTIC takes a bite and hands it to ANTON.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ¢’non, you’re telling me nobody was interested? “ANTON . I speak no English. I have no money. American coaches, powerful coaches, are not helping. I drink too much... (drifting into Russian) ...Beda ni prikhodit odna.

dialogues.speaker: DOUG
dialogues.text: What’s that mean?

dialogues.speaker: ANTON
dialogues.text: Bad shit never comes alone. (a bite of turkey) So I drive cab. I write letters. I master language of English. (he grins) I come here.  33

dialogues.speaker: DOUG
dialogues.text: What’s he pay you to coach her? ANTON flashes a cagey smile. It’s too good to talk about.

dialogues.speaker: _ DOUG
dialogues.text: So what do you do with it all?

dialogues.speaker: ANTON
dialogues.text: I have daughter. In Leningrad. I send dollars through Hungary.

dialogues.speaker: DOUG
dialogues.text: She’s a skater?

dialogues.speaker: ANTON
dialogues.text: No. My daughter is nurse. DOUG nods. .A pause. ANTON watches him, suddenly serious.

dialogues.speaker: ANTON
dialogues.text: You wonder how I leave family behind, yes?

dialogues.speaker: DOUG
dialogues.text: It’s none of my business.

dialogues.speaker: ANTON
dialogues.text: Was very @ifficult time for me. Selfish time. Much unpopularity for me in Russia. Much unhappiness. Is no excuse. Is explanation. (he’s choking up) I am sorry...Thanksgiving, my heart is close to the skin. DOUG nods, takes back the drumstick. They stare out over the water as the MONTAGE THEME COMES UP and <- cUT TO:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: In the BG, A JANITOR drives a ZAMBONI around the ice. KAT and DOUG are seated on the sidelines. She’s reading. He’s impatiently taping up a hockey stick. KATE looks over.

dialogues.speaker: KATE
dialogues.text: If you’re so bored, why don’t you read?

dialogues.speaker: DOUG
dialogues.text: What? You mean a book?

dialogues.speaker: KATE
dialogues.text: That is a traditionally accepted format, yes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: DOUG grunts. Continues with the stick.

dialogues.speaker: KATE
dialogues.text: Don’t you ever read?

dialogues.speaker: DOUG
dialogues.text: Like what?

dialogues.speaker: KATE
dialogues.text: I don’t know, TV Guide?

dialogues.speaker: DOUG
dialogues.text: Hey, look, I can read.

dialogues.speaker: KATE
dialogues.text: So what’s the last book you read? (he shrugs) You were in college.

dialogues.speaker: DOUG
dialogues.text: The last thing I read in college was the letter cancelling my scholarship when I couldn’t play anymore.

dialogues.speaker: KATE
dialogues.text: You must’ve had to read a book in high school.

dialogues.speaker: DOUG
dialogues.text: I was a hockey player. I’ve been. a hockey player since I was nine. The only thing a hockey player has to be able to read is the penalty clock.

dialogues.speaker: KATE
dialogues.text: And they graduated you?

dialogues.speaker: DOUG
dialogues.text: Graduated me? They revered me. I was a God.

dialogues.speaker: KATE
dialogues.text: What a tragic commentary on our times.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: State championships, my last game, grown men wept like children. Two hundred people carried me on their shoulders around the ice until the Minnesota State Police came to break it up. The ZAMBONI heads off the ice. 3g

dialogues.speaker: KATE
dialogues.text: So what were you planning on doing when your gladiating days were over?

dialogues.speaker: DOUG
dialogues.text: You can bet your tights I never thought I’d be working in a freakshow like this.

dialogues.speaker: ANTON
dialogues.text: (entering behind them) Children! On the ice please. KATE stands, pulls her skate guards, turns to DOUG.

dialogues.speaker: KATE ,
dialogues.text: I’m surprised you don’t just chuck it all and start your own think tank.

dialogues.speaker: DOUG
dialogues.text: You‘’re pretty sure I don’t know what that means, aren’t you? KATE smiles. Skates away. DOUG stands there, hating her.

dialogues.speaker: DOUG
dialogues.text: (under his breath) Bitch.

dialogues.speaker: . KATE
dialogues.text: (she heard him) Boob. . cUT TO:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Snow on the ground. Christmas lights on evergreens.

dialogues.speaker: CUT TO
dialogues.text: ‘INT. KATE’S LOCKER ROOM -- DAY KATE, half-dressed, is startled by a KNOCK AT THE DOOR --

dialogues.speaker: KATE
dialogues.text: -- You want to hang on please! DOUG comes through the door. KATE grabs frantically for a towel -- barely covering up as --

dialogues.speaker: KATE
dialogues.text: -- What the hell do you think you're -- Did I say come in? DOUG, holding a CRUDELY WRAPPED PACKAGE in his hands, sta his ground, enjoying KATE’s discomfort as she quickly kno the towel above her chest.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: o- Get out! out this second! DOUG smiles, eyes all over her.

dialogues.speaker: DOUG
dialogues.text: Kate, I handle the stuff all the time, it’s not that big a mystery. KATE stands there stiffly. Something challenged in her expression. A moment as she recovers her poise.

dialogues.speaker: DOUG
dialogues.text: Merry Christmas. ‘ (offering the package) Think fast. He tosses the package -- she catches it, almost losing he towel. She stares at him, and then opens her locker, pui: out a DESIGNER-WRAPPED BOX.

dialogues.speaker: KATE
dialogues.text: (hurling it at him) Happy holiday. DOUG snags it before it takes off his head. KATE starts t open hers, DOUG watching. :

dialogues.speaker: DOUG
dialogues.text: Pretty tough, shopping for the girl who has everything.

dialogues.speaker: KATE
dialogues.text: (looking down) Oh...

dialogues.speaker: DOUG
dialogues.text: Actually, I didn’t have much time to shop. KATE holds a worn, vintage CHICAGO BLACKHAWKS JERSEY at arm’s length.

dialogues.speaker: KATE
dialogues.text: An old shirt...

dialogues.speaker: DOUG
dialogues.text: irt? -- Bobby Hull wore that! Bobby Hull for chrissake -- I’ve had that shirt for fifteen years! (Kate stares) Forget it -- you don’t want it, I/1l take it back.

dialogues.speaker: KATE
dialogues.text: No, no -- I like it. Realiy.  KATE finds a smile. DOUG cools.

dialogues.speaker: KATE
dialogues.text: So open yours. DOUG starts on his gift -- pulling off the ribbon and the his expression sours -- A BOOK. .-

dialogues.speaker: DOUG
dialogues.text: «.-"Great Expectations?"

dialogues.speaker: KATE
dialogues.text: (smiling) It was that or "Curious George Plays Hockey." I took a chance. CUT To:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: DOUG, dressed: in an ill-fitting, brown polyester suit an black tie, stands with ANTON at the front door. THE DOOR swings open --: the FULL RUSH OF A LARGE PARTY. JACK MOSE stands there smiling in a tuxedo.

dialogues.speaker: JACK
dialogues.text: Happy New Year! C’mon in! cUuT TO:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: DOUG and ANTON enter a big party, in the grand, upper cru tradition. Prosperous MEN AND WOMEN, in tuxedos and eveni gowns. BUTLERS and WAITERS circle with champagne and tray of food. A DANCE BAND plays from THE BALLROOM. DOUG stares around, amazed. This is exactly how the other half lives. And then his gaze settles on --

dialogues.speaker: THE MARBLE STAIRCASE
dialogues.text: KATE gathered with a GROUP OF PEOPLE. She is resplendent; .devastating in a tight, .drop-dead, strapless.gown. We k she looked good, but we have never seen her like this. A tall, sandy-haired, TUXEDOED MAN in his late twenties, pu his arm around her waist, as the GROUP breaks into laught DOUG stands there, gaping. A passing BUTLER proffers a tray of champagne glasses. DOUG grabs one, drains it fast

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: PARTY SOUNDS (OS). DOUG at the mirror. Pulling at his hai Brushing his cheap suit. Tugging his tie. No improvement. He’s never felt more like a hick in his life.

dialogues.speaker: CUT TO
dialogues.text: 42  43 INT. JACK’S STUDY/ TROPHY ROOM PARTY SOUNDS (OS). DOUG alone, in a corner, staring at a COLLECTION OF PHOTOGRAPHS distanced slightly from the res INSERT THE PHOTOS -- Black and whites, with a texture and atmosphere that dates them from the fifties. Featured in picture is a young woman skater, KATE’S MOTHER, in variou poses on the ice: Dancing -- Alone -- Surrounded by an Ic Capades-type chorus line. She is beautiful, glamorous; th glow of a powerfully unique personality shines through. DOUG steps away from this shrine, starts for the door, wh

dialogues.speaker: KATE
dialogues.text: (entering) ~~ Hale? (seeing Doug) Oh...

dialogues.speaker: DOUG
dialogues.text: I was just looking --

dialogues.speaker: KATE
dialogues.text: Weren’t these doors closed?

dialogues.speaker: DOUG
dialogues.text: Sort of, but... KATE moves aside; she wants him out. DOUG passes into --

dialogues.speaker: THE HALLWAY
dialogues.text: as KATE closes the doors tightly behind them.

dialogues.speaker: KATE
dialogues.text: It’s not a museun. DOUG, about to apologize, realizes KATE is staring at his outfit.

dialogues.speaker: DOUG
dialogues.text: (self-conscious) Black tie, I thought --

dialogues.speaker: KATE
dialogues.text: Yes, your tie jis black. DOUG stiffens, vulnerable, ready for her to lay him out.

dialogues.speaker: , KATE
dialogues.text: (softening) Don’t worry about it.

dialogues.speaker: DOUG
dialogues.text: Anton should’ve told me.

dialogues.speaker: KATE
dialogues.text: It’s not that big a deal. A WAITER passes with champagne. DOUG grabs two glasses, desperate to change the subject.

dialogues.speaker: DOUG
dialogues.text: I was gonna tell you, that book you gave me, it’s something else.

dialogues.speaker: KATE
dialogues.text: (with a smile) Really? Are you using it as a door stop or a coaster?

dialogues.speaker: DOUG
dialogues.text: (handing her a glass) . Very funny. .

dialogues.speaker: KATE
dialogues.text: I don’t drink.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dou. ‘ | It’s only champagne.

dialogues.speaker: KATE
dialogues.text: I’ve never had a drink in my life.

dialogues.speaker: DOUG
dialogues.text: i e . You’re kidding, right? (she stares back, definitely not kidding) What is it, the calories?

dialogues.speaker: KATE
dialogues.text: (bristling) Considering your knowledge of self contrel is about as extensive as your wardrobe, I’d hardly expect you to understand.

dialogues.speaker: DOUG
dialogues.text: c’mon Kate, everybody’s got to cut loose sometime. It’s New Years Eve for chrissake -- one glass...

dialogues.speaker: KATE
dialogues.text: As thrilling as this moment may be for you, it’s hardly what I would describe as transformational. THE MAN we saw with Kate on the stairs steps INTO FRAME.

dialogues.speaker: NN , MAN
dialogues.text: . Kate, there you are....

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ur THE MAN leans in -- suddenly aware of DOUG’s presence.

dialogues.speaker: KATE
dialogues.text: Hale, this is Doug. Doug Dorsey, Hale Forrestal. HALE is instantly focused. A quick patrician smile.

dialogues.speaker: HALE
dialogues.text: Well, finally...The Secret Weapon. I’ve heard so much about you. HALE offers his hand, DOUG stuck with the two glasses, no

dialogues.speaker: HALE
dialogues.text: May I? (plucking one) This calls for a toast. DOUG chafes under HALE’s inspection.

dialogues.speaker: DOUG
dialogues.text: Let’s drink to the little people. HALE blinks as DOUG drains his glass. KATE watches them.

dialogues.speaker: HALE
dialogues.text: I understand you were at the University of Minnesota.

dialogues.speaker: DOUG
dialogues.text: For a while.

dialogues.speaker: HALE
dialogues.text: I played a little hockey myself. For fun. :

dialogues.speaker: DOUG
dialogues.text: (flatly) Yeah? Let me know sometime, we’1l slap it around.

dialogues.speaker: KATE
dialogues.text: If you two will excuse me, naked male insecurity really leaves me cold. KATE walks. HALE and DOUG left staring after her. HALE, recovering his swagger, turns back to DOUG.

dialogues.speaker: DOUG
dialogues.text: So, dude, back for long? A pause. HALE regards DOUG unpleasantly.
aay oO

dialogues.speaker: HALE
dialogues.text: Just several days. We/ve been very busy in the London office. But then I gather you’ve been on quite a schedule as well. Douc Jack. likes to get his money’s worth.

dialogues.speaker: HALE
dialogues.text: I understand you've been giving Kate a rough time of it.

dialogues.speaker: DOUG
dialogues.text: You know Kate.

dialogues.speaker: HALE
dialogues.text: Yes, I do. For quite a while. And I don’t like to see her upset.

dialogues.speaker: DOUG
dialogues.text: I was you, I’d invest in blindfolds. Before HALE can find his tongue, DOUG is walking away.

dialogues.speaker: THE PARTY -
dialogues.text: THE BALLROOM.: THE BAND really playing. On the dance floo ANTON tearing it up with a very spry DOWAGER.

dialogues.speaker: THE PARTY
dialogues.text: KATE stands near a buffet table with several SOCIALITES. As THEY BANTER, KATE’S eyes drift across the room -~ her expression souring as she watches -- DOUG -- ACROSS THE ROOM -- standing with TWO 18-YEAR-OLD DEBUTANTES. We can’t hear what he’s saying from this far away, but whatever it is, the DEBS are loving it; gigglin and flirting like crazy.

dialogues.speaker: THE PARTY
dialogues.text: THE CROWD gathered in the BALLROOM. THE BANDLEADER counti down the final seconds of 1991 --

dialogues.speaker: BANDLEADER
dialogues.text: ...ten...nine... (the crowd joining in) +..-eight...seven... IN THE BACK OF THE ROOM -- DOUG alone in the doorway.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: an THE CROWD -+.Six...five... A FEW YARDS AWAY -- KATE reaches down to manuever HALE’s hand off her ass. .

dialogues.speaker: THE CROWD
dialogues.text: ...four...three...two...one...

dialogues.speaker: HAPPY NEW YEAR
dialogues.text: HORNS -~- CONFETTI -- "AULD LANG SYNE" == COUPLES embrace DOUG is grabbed by ONE OF THE DEBUTANTES for a big kiss, and then he’s passed to THE SECOND DEBUTANTE, another kis and then he’s handed over to AN OLDER WOMAN and -- SEVERAL YARDS OFF <= KATE pulled from HALE’s embrace into arms of AN OLDER MAN and then passed to ANOTHER MAN and t MUSIC’S GOING and COUPLES all over the room are doing the thing and KATE is surrendering to the moment when suddenl

dialogues.speaker: DOUG AND KATE
dialogues.text: thrust into each other’s arms, instinctively moving towar a kiss -- when suddenly THEY FREEZE. A dead stop. KATE recoils. DOUG stiffens. And then, pretending it never happened, they turn away into the crowd.

dialogues.speaker: THE BUFFET ROOM -
dialogues.text: MUSIC echoing from the ballroom. DOUG enters, grabs a BOTTLE OF CHAMPAGNE from an ice bucket and keeps on going

dialogues.text: INT. KATE’S BEDROOM -- LATER Dark. Kate’s gown crumpled in a mess on the floor. Hale’s tuxedo folded carefully over a chair. IN BED'-- HALE asleep and snoring. KATE, beside him, is w awake, looking tense and unsatisfied. She stands, pulling sheet around her, moving across the room to THE WINDOW. She listens, then THROWS THE WINDOW OPEN and stares out. The FAINT SOUND OF ROCK AND ROLL playing from somewhere.

dialogues.speaker: POUNDING ROCK AND ROLL ECHOES THROUGH THE BUILDING. DOUG,
dialogues.text: alone, on the ice. Hockey stick in hand. Dozens of pucks littered around the ice. A private moment of total free-f mania. DOUG skating, blitzing -- firing pucks against the wall like a man possesed; like a man who has no choice bu burn off his reckless energy before it kills him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ANTON stands at the front door, talking with KATE.

dialogues.speaker: KATE
dialogues.text: What do you mean, we’re taking the weekend off?

dialogues.speaker: ANTON
dialogues.text: Just till Monday. Is three days. He works very hard. We make much progress. (she’s waiting for details) Steam is needing to be blown off. You know...outside contact....

dialogues.speaker: KATE
dialogues.text: When you say outside contact what exactly are we talking about?

dialogues.speaker: ANTON
dialogues.text: Katya, please, is not boy. Is man. Young vigorous man. (he tries a smile) Too much...solitude is not good. . e@ KATE ue We work seven days a week. We work Thanksgiving. We work Christmas. I have the flu, and we work. I have a boyfriend in London, and we work. I show up every day of the week and skate a remedial pairs clinic so you can play Dr. Frankenstein with this goon! I show up ready to work every day for nineteen weeks and now you give him two days off so he can go ‘whoring around New York?

dialogues.speaker: . ANTON
dialogues.text: : Is not entirely correct. (Kate stares) He went to Boston. - As THE DOOR SLAMS SHUT in his face.

dialogues.speaker: WHITE SCREEN
dialogues.text: TWO PAIRS OF SKATES -- both in mid-air, SLICE INTO FRAME. SUPER-SLOW MOTION as they turn, glistening above the ice. . Touching down, the SLOW MOTION ACCELERATES -- MUSIC FAD Vo. IN -- THE CAMERA BEGINS TO PULL AWAY -- SUPERIMPOSE:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: KATE AND DOUG IN THE DOME -- skating the hell out of a re routine. ‘ They’ve gotten very good -- arabesque into a d toe loop throw -- KATE in the air -- landing in DOUG’s ar and into the big finish as THE MUSIC PEAKS -- a side-by-s blur spin at center ice as THE NUMBER ENDS.

dialogues.speaker: OFF THE ICE -
dialogues.text: HOUSEKEEPERS all applauding. KATE AND DOUG -- rise from their finishing positions. The nuclear winter of their past relationship has warmed over time into a grudging respect.

dialogues.speaker: KATE
dialogues.text: You’re still rushing the Lutz.

dialogues.speaker: DOUG
dialogues.text: Maybe you just ought to go with it. (Kate looks over, Doug smiles) Do what I do -- just close your eyes and commit. KATE is about to rebut, as JACK and ANTON bound onto the

dialogues.speaker: JACK
dialogues.text: Just tremendous! Tremendous! HALE, in loafers, slips and slides awkwardly toward thes

dialogues.speaker: HALE
dialogues.text: Honey, you were terrific! THEY ALL turn as HALE falls on his ass onto the ice.

dialogues.speaker: THE CAMERA CIRCLES THE TABLE
dialogues.text: A WAITER standing-by and FINALLY TO -- DOUG transformed -- at least partially: A well-tailored « Tanned and fit. Long hair pulled back stylishly. Hardiy the oafish rube we remember from New Year’s Eve party.

dialogues.speaker: DOUG
dialogues.text: I’1l have the terrine of seafood, followed by the steak au poivre, and I’d like that rare please. The WAITER nods, backs away. JACK leans into the table

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Let’s get down to business. It’s Labor Day weekend, where do we stand?

dialogues.speaker: ANTON
dialogues.text: First is to get Douglas eligible.

dialogues.speaker: DOUG
dialogues.text: What’s that going to be like?

dialogues.speaker: ANTON
dialogues.text: For you is like test pilot taking driver’s exam.

dialogues.speaker: JACK
dialogues.text: And then into the sectionals?

dialogues.speaker: ANTON
dialogues.text: We skip sectionals. They turn -- this is news -- ANTON pulls a book from his bag, places it on the table. ANTON . USFSA rule number eight-hundred and twenty-three... (he opens the book begins to read--) "Former World Team Pairs members competing with eligible partners may receive, upon application to the Executive Council, a bye into the National Championships."

dialogues.speaker: DOUG
dialogues.text: Straight to the nationals?

dialogues.speaker: JACK
dialogues.text: I love it.

dialogues.speaker: KATE
dialogues.text: You’re kidding.

dialogues.speaker: ANTON
dialogues.text: Rule is rule. Who expects former champion to skate with unknown. (he closes the book) January five. New Orleans.

dialogues.speaker: JACK
dialogues.text: And then the Olympics in February. (he grins) I smell gold... The table brims with confidence. Only ANTON dissents.

dialogues.speaker: ANTON
dialogues.text: Hopes perhaps must be scaled back.

dialogues.speaker: DOUG
dialogues.text: What’re you talking about?

dialogues.speaker: ANTON
dialogues.text: Figure skating is not like hockey. Team scoring most goals does not always win. This is yery small world. People will not be rushing to welcome us. (looking around) I am outsider. Douglas is freak. Katya...well... (he lets this go) Let’s just say we are having three strikes against us. To be winning place on team we will have to be best by very much.

dialogues.speaker: JACK
dialogues.text: So we’ll be the best.

dialogues.speaker: HALE
dialogues.text: (raising his glass) To success. ,

dialogues.speaker: DOUG
dialogues.text: Hell, we can do better than that. (Hale stops--) I say we kick some butt.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That’s the ticket! -- Let’s drink to kicking butt. THEY clink glasses and sip -- KATE drinking soda.

dialogues.speaker: HALE
dialogues.text: I have another announcement to make. (he looks at Kate) . Jack’s seen fit to transfer me back to the home office in New York, and Kate and I... (he hesitates) «.ewell, we’re going to be married this winter,

dialogues.speaker: KATE
dialogues.text: (correcting him) I told you -- the Spring. After competition.

dialogues.speaker: HALE
dialogues.text: Spring, winter, whatever.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 52 JACK and ANTON break huge grins. HALE, beaming, puts his arm around KATE’s shoulder, CLOSE-UP -- DOUG -- as this news registers. He’s stunned, and more than that, he’s stunned that he’s stunned. WE HO ON HIM for this next:

dialogues.speaker: JACK, (OVER)
dialogues.text: Oh Katie...it’s about time! I was wondering how long I’d have to wait!

dialogues.speaker: ANTON, (OVER)
dialogues.text: This becomes quite the night, Katya, please, my kiss. DOUG rallies, summons a hearty smile.

dialogues.speaker: DOUG
dialogues.text: Congratulations. That’s great.

dialogues.speaker: HALE, (OVER)
dialogues.text: Show them the ring, Kate.

dialogues.speaker: JACK, (OVER)
dialogues.text: My God...Now that’s a piece of ice. STILL ON DOUG -- as the conversation DRIFTS AWAY away and curT To:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Brightly lit and practically deserted. On the ice, a ten-year-old GIRL skates to the final chorus of "TOMORROW She almost falls, recovers, and it’s over. OFF THE ICE -- THREE TEST JUDGES sit at a desk marked: USFSA TESTING. The JUDGES check off their scores and nod approvingly at the GIRL, who nervously exits the ice.

dialogues.speaker: WOMAN JUDGE
dialogues.text: (calling around the rink) Male senior pairs test. Skaters twelve and thirteen, please.

dialogues.speaker: IN THE RUNWAY
dialogues.text: KATE AND DOUG wearing plain, elegant warm-up suits, emerg ANTON in the shadows behind then.

dialogues.speaker: ON THE SIDELINES
dialogues.text: The JUDGES and a SMALL GROUP of YOUNG SKATERS, PARENTS, a COACHES gathered behind them, react with amazement:

dialogues.speaker: GROUP
dialogues.text: --Mommy, that’s Kate Moseley! ~-It’s Kate Moseley! --Couldn’t be... --My God, it is... KATE AND DOUG skate to center ice, as the GROUP falls sil

dialogues.speaker: WOMAN JUDGE
dialogues.text: (very surprised) Kate, well... Nice to see you back.

dialogues.speaker: KATE
dialogues.text: It’s nice to be here.

dialogues.speaker: MALE JUDGE

THE GROUP OF SKATERS AND PARENTS watch in awe. This is something special and they know it. cUuT TO: INT. DOUG’S APARTMENT -- NIGHT The place is a mess, but a mess with a new slant -- BOOKS littered all over -- SKATING TAPES stacked by the VCR. DOUG is sprawled on the couch, reading. A KNOCK AT THE DO

dialogues.text: The one with the mask.

dialogues.speaker: DOUG
dialogues.text: What keeps you going, Kate? (she turns) Do you really like to skate? if ‘she'd never considered this question before.

dialogues.speaker: DOUG

dialogues.text: ue ov

dialogues.text: You're still dropping your shoulder on the exit. _ KATE, shocked, skates closer for a better look.

dialogues.text: I thought you’d retired.

dialogues.speaker: TUTTLE
dialogues.text: I heard. You know what I think is the saddest thing about sports: people who stay too long at the party. (he smiles) You were a great champion, Kate. We had a nice run. Maybe it ended badly, but I blame myself for that.

dialogues.speaker: KATE
dialogues.text: What are you doing here, Rick?

dialogues.speaker: TUTTLE
dialogues.text: I’m saying I’d like to see you go out a champion.

dialogues.text: That’s the plan.  64

dialogues.speaker: KATE
dialogues.text: ? You spent ten years tying me into knots!

(she laughs) I skated through fire for you. I turned myself inside out trying to please you, and it was never, ever enough, was it?

dialogues.speaker: TUTTLE

dialogues.text: (sensing blood) Come on, Kate, this guy, a hockey player... : (he smiles) I mean, let’s face it, trusting partners has never been your strong suit. KATE takes a deep breath, willing herself calm.

dialogues.speaker: KATE
dialogues.text: Just so you know, before you get the hell out of my building -- this guy, this hockey player, is the best skater I’ve ever been on the ice with. He’s going to make you cry he’s so good.  on ui TUTTLE says nothing. A moment.

KATE ‘ (she means it) You let me down, I swear to God, I’ll knock out what’s left of your teeth.
